Universal Accessibility: If the internet became a basic human right, it would mean that every individual on the planet would have access to it, regardless of their geographical location or socio-economic status. This would greatly enhance the quality of life for people in remote or underserved areas, as they would have access to a wealth of information, educational resources, and opportunities for connectivity with the rest of the world.

Enhanced Social Mobility: By providing equal access to the internet, basic human rights would help bridge the digital divide, enabling people to access new job opportunities, educational resources, and social networks. This would help reduce inequality and promote social mobility, as individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds would have the same opportunities as those from more privileged backgrounds.

Improved Healthcare: The internet has revolutionized healthcare by providing access to medical information, telemedicine services, and remote consultations. If the internet became a basic human right, people would have access to better healthcare services, regardless of their location or financial means. This would lead to improved health outcomes, as individuals would be able to access quality medical care and advice more easily.

Enhanced Democracy: The internet has the potential to promote democratic values by providing a platform for free speech, open communication, and the exchange of ideas. If the internet became a basic human right, people would have greater freedom of expression, and governments would be held accountable for their actions. This would lead to more transparent and accountable governance, as citizens would be able to access information and hold their leaders to account.

Increased Economic Opportunities: The internet has the potential to create new economic opportunities by providing access to global markets, enabling entrepreneurs to start and grow their businesses, and connecting people with potential customers and partners. If the internet became a basic human right, people would have access to these opportunities, regardless of their location or financial means. This would lead to increased economic growth and development, as individuals and businesses would be able to participate in the global economy more easily.
